articleBody: Learning Objectives â€¢ Understand the principles of abstract photography focusing on visual elements. â€¢ Experiment with different compositions and techniques to create abstract images. â€¢ Develop a personal style by critically evaluating and reflecting on their work. Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Choose a location with interesting patterns or textures, such as an urban setting or natural landscape. â€¢ Gather a variety of objects to photograph close-up, focusing on their shapes and textures. â€¢ Set your camera to aperture priority mode with a fixed ISO of 200. â€¢ Familiarize yourself with the rule of thirds and negative space concepts. â€¢ Prepare to experiment with light and shadow by selecting different times of day for shooting. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Use aperture priority mode to control depth of field and isolate subjects. â€¢ Incorporate intentional camera movement to create dynamic abstract effects. â€¢ Experiment with macro photography to capture fine details of everyday objects. â€¢ Explore the effects of backlighting to enhance shapes and textures. â€¢ Use a tripod to stabilize your shots during longer exposures for smooth abstract images. Creative Focus â€¢ Seek inspiration in mundane objects around your environment to find abstract potential. â€¢ Play with reflections in water or glass to create layered images. â€¢ Use color contrasts to evoke emotions and add depth to your images. â€¢ Capture shadows and silhouettes to emphasize shapes and forms. â€¢ Experiment with different angles and perspectives to challenge traditional viewpoints. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Find a textured surface (like a wall or fabric) and shoot a close-up image using aperture priority mode at f/4 with ISO 200 fixed to create depth. â€¢ Capture an abstract image of moving water, using shutter priority mode at 1/100s with ISO 200 fixed to freeze the motion. â€¢ Photograph a collection of everyday objects from above, ensuring to fill the frame with shapes, using aperture priority mode at f/5.6 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Use intentional camera movement while shooting a busy street scene, using shutter priority mode at 1/30s with ISO 200 fixed to create a sense of motion. â€¢ Create an abstract image focusing on light and shadow by shooting through a translucent material using aperture priority mode at f/2.8 with ISO 200 fixed. â€¢ Find an urban environment with patterns (like pavement or buildings) and shoot from a low angle, using aperture priority mode at f/8 with ISO 200 fixed to capture depth. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Develop a series of 5 images that tell a story through abstract photography, using various techniques learned in this assignment. â€¢ Create a photo collage of your abstract images, focusing on color and shape relationships to convey a theme. DO / DON'T DO â€¢ âœ“ Do explore different locations for varied abstract opportunities. â€¢ âœ“ Do take multiple shots from different angles to find the most compelling composition. â€¢ âœ“ Do adjust your framing to include negative space for a more balanced composition. â€¢ âœ“ Do review and edit your photos to enhance colors and contrast after the shoot. â€¢ âœ“ Do seek feedback from peers or mentors to gain insights into your abstract work. DON'T â€¢ âœ— Don't rely on literal representations; focus on the essence of the subject instead. â€¢ âœ— Don't be afraid to experiment; failure can lead to unexpected and rewarding results. â€¢ âœ— Don't shoot in direct sunlight without considering shadows, as they can overwhelm your composition. â€¢ âœ— Don't ignore the importance of composition; the arrangement of elements is crucial in abstract photography. â€¢ âœ— Don't use too many elements in one frame; simplicity often leads to stronger abstract images.
